newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Weak prices harming rubber trade, Malaysia say.
newsitem.headline: Weak prices harming rubber trade, Malaysia say.

text.p: The global rubber trade is being hit by weak prices and Malaysia's Primary Industries Minister Lim Keng Yaik has warned consumers that driving prices lower could backfire and disrupt supply.

"It pays in the long run to give natural rubber the fair remunerative prices which the industry seeks, otherwise, consumers will be faced with a real shortage when they need rubber, Lim told the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board's annual dinner late on Friday.

He said consumers were doing their best to push rubber prices to their lowest levels in Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia -- the world's largest rubber producers -- and Singapore, the main trading centre for the commodity.

Lim said rapid industrialisation and rising costs in Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand were already shrinking rubber plantations, which sometimes have to make way for more lucrative crops or property development.
"If they don't get the prices they want, these countries may not find it worthwhile producing rubber any more," he warned.
Regional rubber markets have been depressed over the past two months due to thin demand from consumers, awaiting better prices after meeting their short-covering needs.

Lim said Malaysia's benchmark Ribbed Smoked Sheet One (RSS1) and Standard Malaysian Rubber 20 fetched average prices of 362.70 cents ($1.46) per kilogramme and 337 cents per kg in the first nine months of 1996, compared to 393.61 and 382.60 for the whole of 1995.
The Finance Ministry said in its annual economic report on Friday that RSS1 was expected to average 370 cents a kg for the whole of 1996 and 300 cents in 1997.

"Although we can look at this as a breather for the market, it will still be better if the prices are stable," Lim said. "We certainly don't want the RSS1 to fall to around 200 cents (a kg). It should ideally be around 350 cents," Lim said.
